course_title: Freshman Seminar:Anthropology: Do Black Lives Matter?
class_notes: This course is a discussion based seminar that uses critical insights from cultural anthropology, Black studies, literature, and popular culture to analyze a key site of struggle for Black life in the United States: mass incarceration. The United States has the largest prison population in the world and the highest per-capita incarceration rate, and Black communities in the US are disproportionately impacted by this reality. This course will explore the ways that racial, economic, and gender-based inequalities have led to the proliferation of prisons and jails in the United States, and the ways that Black communities have critiqued and organized against the rise of the carceral state.
course_description: Seminar on various anthropological topics. Satisfies general education Freshman Seminar.
